summary: This is an email chain from March 2019 regarding travel approval for Assistant U.S. Attorney Alex Rossmiller to conduct meetings and interviews in Florida for the investigation United States v. Epstein, relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.role: U.S. Attorney's Office employee (likely supervisor/approving official)
persons.context: Appears as the sender of the approval email, instructing the recipient to get the travel request into the E2 system.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: Copied on the approval email from Edward Tyrrell.

persons.name: Alex Rossmiller
persons.context: The author of the initial travel request email, seeking permission to travel to Florida for meetings and interviews related to the Epstein investigation.

connections.description: Tyrrell approves Rossmiller's travel request, indicating a supervisory or approval authority relationship within the U.S. Attorney's Office.
Tyrrell copies Duncan on the approval email, suggesting a working relationship within the same office.
Both are part of the same U.S. Attorney's Office correspondence chain regarding official travel.

events.title: Travel Request Submission
events.description: Assistant U.S. Attorney Alex Rossmiller submits a request for travel to Florida for meetings and interviews related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel Approval Granted
events.description: Edward Tyrrell approves the travel request for the Epstein investigation, instructing the recipient to log it in the E2 system.

events.title: Planned Travel to Florida
events.description: The planned travel for the investigation team to fly to Florida for meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale.

keyFacts: The document is a 2019 internal email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding travel for the Epstein investigation.
The investigation is formally titled 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618' and relates to 'enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
Prosecutors were traveling to Florida (West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale) for meetings and interviews, indicating active investigative work in that region years after Epstein's initial Florida case.
The email shows standard bureaucratic procedure (travel approval via E2 system) within the DOJ for a high-profile investigation.
